block.p: Vivendi Is Said to Offer To Sell Its BSkyB Stake Vivendi, the French conglomerate, has offered to sell its 23 percent stake in British Sky Broadcasting to secure European regulatory approval of its $34 billion purchase of Seagram, a person close to the negotiations said.

The offer to sell the stake in BSkyB, a large pay-television concern controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, came on the eve of a decision by European antitrust regulators over whether to approve the Vivendi-Seagram deal, which would transform Vivendi into a leading entertainment power. [Page C7.]

G.M. Profit Falls but Beats Forecast General Motors said that its third-quarter profit dropped 5.5 percent, slightly better than forecasts, but said that fourth-quarter earnings might fall short of estimates. [C2.]

Top Officers Resign at WebMD Jeffrey Arnold, who put together the Internet health company WebMD and merged it with Healtheon, resigned as co-chief executive. At the same time, Jim Clark, the founder of Healtheon, resigned from the board. Martin J. Wygod took full control as the remaining chief executive of the troubled company. Shares of WebMD fell $1.19, to to $8.50. [C2.]

Veto Promised on Bankruptcy Bill Congressional efforts to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system appeared all but doomed when the White House said that President Clinton would veto a last-ditch measure that sailed through the House. [A24.]
Chinese Factory to Supply RU-486 A Chinese factory near Shanghai will soon begin exporting to the United States RU-486, the abortion pill recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration. [C7.]

Urbanfetch to Close Its Web Site Urbanfetch.com, the online delivery service that was started in New York less than a year ago to compete with Kozmo.com, announced that it was shutting down its Web site and would lay off more than 160 employees. Urbanfetch officials said they would continue operating its business courier company. [A28.]

Corn Developer Cancels License The Environmental Protection Agency said that Aventis, the developer of the genetically engineered corn that has been linked to the recalls of two brands of taco shells, had agreed to voluntarily cancel its marketing license. [C5.]

Soros to Buy Control of Bluefly The George Soros hedge fund group plans to announce today that it is taking over the struggling Internet retailer Bluefly, a person close to the situation said. Mr. Soros has already spent heavily on Bluefly -- $21.2 million for preferred stock, short-term bonds and warrants to buy more shares. His firm has also made a commitment to provide $3 million more in financing this year. [C7.]

Import Prices, Minus Oil, Fall 0.3% Prices of imports other than oil fell 0.3 percent last month, the largest decline in one and a half years last, government figures showed, suggesting the nation's appetite for foreign-made goods is helping contain inflation. [C2.]

Chief of Tomkins in Britain Quits Tomkins, a British conglomerate with businesses that range from windshield wiper blades to Smith & Wesson handguns, said that its chief executive, Greg Hutchings, had resigned after the company learned of ''corporate excesses.'' [World Business, Section W.]
